title: Weaving Tabular Datasets using ThreadsheetR
text: working PhD dissertation (chapter Cold War diplomacy didn’t make final version…) found trying juggle hundreds different datasets, OCRed .csv format, sources like US State Department, CIA, official Soviet statistical publications. source used different conventions (e.g., names countries regions) structures (e.g., countries \(x\)-axis years \(y\)-axis, others just three columns: country, year, value). , even get stage able impute missing datapoints, find way align different formats. ’s task 1 threadsheetr automates us. , second problem arose: first, (say) two differing estimates given country-year pair, get away just creating new “master dataset” whose cells represented manually-computed averages two estimates. project progressed, however, realized way pay grade: ’d 4, 5, sometimes 6 estimates given quantity, decided remove one, downweight one sources less trustworthy, use median instead mean… Every cell master dataset re-calculated. realized needed way automate task, threadsheetr born. summary, three main problems threadsheetr sets solve : Datasets range non-standard formats—wide, long, multiple headers, etc.: threadsheetr parses different datapoints different input files can compared, aggregated, imputed, etc. Datasets disagree underlying value: Given aggregation function set “trust scores”, threadsheetr automates process combining individual estimates single “master dataset” containing trust-weighted average individual estimates. Datasets missing data: R packages like mice provide sophisticated data imputation algorithms used intensive data-concordance tasks, threadsheetr contains implementations simple data imputation algorithms allow generation “ballpark” estimates missing values (part larger grid aggregated estimate values) addition, threadsheetr interfaces GitHub Google Sheets produce interactive color-coded master data grids, allowing visualize current state data aggregation/imputation: Green cells, example, represent values sources agreement, yellow cells represent conflicting values. Crucially, hovering mouse columns brings popover box containing description estimate arrived : hovering yellow cells, example, can see listing source file used, respective trust weights estimates cell’s value.

title: Weaving Tabular Datasets using ThreadsheetR
text: demo ’ll walk process went , dissertation, generate aggregated grid country \(\times\) year Communist Party membership estimates. data come two main sources: Strength World Communist Parties: US State Department publication, issued yearly 1963 1973. appended together, get long-format dataset: row represents (country,year) pair. Hoover Yearbook World Communism: Yearly statistics compiled Hoover Institution, 1971 1990. yearbook provides “checklist” wherein row represents country, appended together get long-format dataset: row represents (country,year) pair. Along two additional miscellaneous sources provided rich data particular years/regions: Handbook Statistical Social Science Data: Provides membership estimates select years 1924 1968, wide format (row represents country, column represents year) Statistical Abstract Latin America: Provides yearly membership estimates Latin American countries 1947 1976, wide format (row represents country, column represents year) Part difficulty, therefore, came fact first two datasets given long format, latter two wide (grid) format. Thus first step, now describe, threadsheetr detects format input file transforms standardized long format, format (unlike wide format) allow us record multiple estimates single (country,year) pair.

what: Step 0: Specifying the Structure of the Data
title: Weaving Tabular Datasets using ThreadsheetR
text: can run threadsheetr library functions, need create specification file record format grid want generate: varname: name variable want generate grid alt_names: alternative names variable might various datasets. datatype: data type ’d like cells generated grid (boolean, int, float, string) rounding: algorithm encounters need round: error, algorithm terminates need round encountered, warn warning message printed algorithm continues rounding, ignore algorithm just performs rounding continues. unit_of_obs: name index variable panel dataset (example, id survey respondent, name country) time_varname: name time variable panel dataset (example, month current row’s survey, year country’s value estimated) time_start: first value time_varname want generated grid time_end: last value time_varname want generated grid Rules transform various values algorithm encounters, enable different formats input datasets comported. case, variable want create rules , provide: varname: name index variable altnames: alternative names index variable might across various datasets ffill: TRUE, missing values index variable filled closest non-missing value . FALSE (provided), missing values retained lowercase TRUE, values index variable lowercased combined (helpful ensuring , example, “Democratic Republic Congo” “Democratic Republic Congo” treated unit) rules: list rules index variable. rule format value1: {operation: value2}. two operations available rename addto, following two forms valid: . oldName: {rename: newName} ii. altname: {addto: name} information given yaml format, saved file .yaml extension. , case vignette, file named demo.yaml following contents (rule list country shortened brevity):
code: --- index_rules:   - varname: year     ffill: true   - varname: country     alt_names: ['area']     lowercase: true     rules:       - "Abu Dhabi": {rename: "United Arab Emirates"}       - "Basutoland": {rename: "Lesotho"}       - "Bechuanaland": {rename: "Botswana"}       - "British Guiana": {rename: "Guyana"}       - "Cameroons": {addto: "Nigeria"} # British Cameroon, became part of Nigeria in 1960       - "Cameroun": {addto: "Cameroon"} # French Cameroon, became modern-day Cameroon       ...       - "Rio Muni": {addto: "Equatorial Guinea"} # The non-continental part of Equatorial Guinea       - "South West Africa": {rename: "Namibia"} # Independence from SA in 1990       - "Southern Rhodesia": {rename: "Zimbabwe"}       - "Tanganyika": {rename: "Tanzania"}       - "TOTALS": {rename: "Total"}       - "Trucial States": {rename: "United Arab Emirates"} # I know it's not 1-to-1 but this makes life a lot easier       - "United Arab Republic": {rename: "Egypt"} # Again, I know... but there's literally only 1 single observation where it's actually Egypt+Syria. All the rest just mean Egypt       - "U.S.S.R.": {rename: "USSR"}       - "Zaire": {rename: "Democratic Republic of the Congo"}       - "Zanzibar": {addto: "Tanzania"} # Tanganyika and Zanzibar merged to become Tanzania in 1964 grid:   varname: cp_membership_num   alt_names: ["cp_membership", "num_members"] # Used as the index if varname isn't found   datatype: int   rounding: warn   unit_of_obs: country   time_varname: year   time_start: 1945   time_end: 1975

text: Wide-format tibble, one row per unit observation one column per unit time

code: grid_df <- threader_create_grid() #> =====[ creating grid for [cp_membership_num] x [country], t={1945, ..., 1975} ]===== #> [1] "Values for grid axis [year]:" #> # A tibble: 22 × 1 #>    year  #>    <chr> #>  1 1947  #>  2 1952  #>  3 1956  #>  4 1957  #>  5 1958  #>  6 1959  #>  7 1960  #>  8 1961  #>  9 1962  #> 10 1963  #> # ℹ 12 more rows #> [1] "Values for grid axis [country]:" #> # A tibble: 286 × 1 #>    country                        #>    <chr>                          #>  1 aden                           #>  2 afghanistan                    #>  3 albania                        #>  4 algeria                        #>  5 angola                         #>  6 angola (see portuguese africa) #>  7 antilles                       #>  8 antilles (netherlands)         #>  9 arabian peninsula              #> 10 argentina                      #> # ℹ 276 more rows

title: Step 1: Parse Data Files — threader_parse
text: Step 1: Parse Data Files

title: Step 1: Parse Data Files — threader_parse
code: threader_parse(data_path = NULL, spec_fpath = NULL, verbose = FALSE)

title: Step 1: Parse Data Files — threader_parse
text: data_path Path directory containing raw data want parse. spec_fpath Filepath .yaml-format spec file verbose Optional: TRUE, prints additional debugging information.

title: Step 1: Parse Data Files — threader_parse
text: environment key input file, value tibble generated data file

Push estimate grid to GitHub — threader_push_to_git
text: combined_path Path directory containing combined (wide-format) grid datasets want push git spec_fpath Filepath .yaml-format spec file.

title: Push estimate grid to GitHub — threader_push_to_git
text: environment keys num_result, return value GH API call pushing numeric grid, info_result, return value GH API call pushing info grid

title: Push estimate grid to GitHub — threader_push_to_git
code: # Not run, since it requires authentication (via `.env` file) #gh_result <- threader_push_to_git()

what: Print a list of summary statistics — threader_sumstats
title: Print a list of summary statistics — threader_sumstats
text: Can used initial diagnostic, check pipeline ran successfully

title: Print a list of summary statistics — threader_sumstats
Print a list of summary statistics — threader_sumstats
text: grid_long_fpath filepath generated long-format grid data group_by_var Optional: provided, sumstats output include number groups generated grouping variable.

title: Print a list of summary statistics — threader_sumstats
text: list keys num_obs, mean_est, num_nonnull, num_null.

title: Print a list of summary statistics — threader_sumstats
code: grid_sumstats <- threader_sumstats() #> N = 6292 (2079 non-NA, 4213 NA) #> Mean Estimate = 416919.920795254
